Carl Grünberg and Felix Weil, the two founders of the Frankfurt School, were both important figures in their own right. Carl Grünberg was a philosopher and legal scholar and was the first director of the Institute for Social Research, the organization that later became known as the Frankfurt School. He was also a professor of law at the University of Frankfurt and was active in the workers' movement. Felix Weil was a young Marxist philosopher and social scientist, who provided the financial support to establish the Institute for Social Research.

Many of the students and scholars associated with the Frankfurt School went on to become influential figures in their own right. Some of the most well-known members of the Frankfurt School include:

* Max Horkheimer, who served as the director of the Institute for Social Research and was an important figure in the development of critical theory.
* Theodor Adorno, who was a philosopher, sociologist, and musicologist, and one of the most important figures in the Frankfurt School.
* Erich Fromm, a psychoanalyst, and social philosopher, who wrote "The Art of Loving" among other books.
* Herbert Marcuse, a philosopher, political theorist, and sociologist, who became famous during the 1960s for his critical analysis of contemporary society and his critiques of technology and consumer culture.
* Jürgen Habermas, a philosopher, sociologist, and political theorist, who is known for his work on communicative action and the public sphere.

In summary, Carl Grünberg and Felix Weil, the two founders of the Frankfurt School, were important figures in their own right, but many of the students and scholars associated with the Frankfurt School went on to become influential figures in their own right, with some of the most well-known members of the Frankfurt School include Max Horkheimer, Theodor Adorno, Erich Fromm, Herbert Marcuse, Jürgen Habermas among others.
